title: 中國大使館既人係華沙打波蘭人

replies.msg:
事源:

On September 14, on Krakowskie Przedmieście the celebration of the 70th anniversary of establishing relations between the People's Republic of China and communist Poland [Bierut - Mao Zedong, 1949] and the rise of communist China was organized. Journalists were physically attacked by the aggressive Chinese, who provocatively banged flags on the banner, journalists’ hands and camera.

9月14號係華沙Old Town，中國大使館既人搞"中波建交70周年"活動。有波蘭人去現場示威，跟住呢條中國大使館既八婆打波蘭記者，同埋想比錢波蘭人打發佢地走。

片link:
https://www.facebook.com/idzpodprad/videos/679355885887404/

事源:

On September 14, on Krakowskie Przedmieście the celebration of the 70th anniversary of establishing relations between the People's Republic of China and communist Poland [Bierut - Mao Zedong, 1949] and the rise of communist China was organized. Journalists were physically attacked by the aggressive Chinese, who provocatively banged flags on the banner, journalists’ hands and camera.

9月14號係華沙Old Town，中國大使館既人搞"中波建交70周年"活動。有波蘭人去現場示威，跟住呢條中國大使館既八婆打波蘭記者，同埋想比錢波蘭人打發佢地走。

replies.msg: 就咁睇人哋面對苦難嗰陣，向佢背後啲以致命一擊

詳細報導
“The Chinese have become aggressive, provocatively banging flags on the banner, our hands and camera. One Chinese woman shouted at us about why we were recording, since nobody allowed us! At one point she hit the camera hard. They were also trying to bribe us, one Chinese showed a bundle of hundred-zloty bills and invited us to the cafe to talk”, the course of events in the capital is reported by Mateusz from the Against the Tide Warsaw club, who filmed the whole incident.

The attack on Poles took place this Saturday in Warsaw, where on Krakowskie Przedmieście Street there was a celebration of the 70th anniversary of the rise of communist China and the establishment of diplomatic relations between the People’s Republic of China and communist Poland (Bolesław Bierut – Mao Zedong, 1949). Against the Tide Warsaw club reminded Poland of the Chinese crime at Tiananmen Square, where 30 years ago, on June 4, 1989, the communists murdered up to 10,000 peaceful protesters. To this day, in the communist China, it is forbidden to talk about the massacre at Beijing’s Tian’anmen Square.

https://againstthetide.tv/2019/09/17/the-chinese-attacked-poles-in-warsaw-video/?fbclid=IwAR1TpT4cTUDLT4WkNKZg68VDLN2eGVvJKy0siMyLHUUlG6S8gGSlPsya1vs

Just before the speech of the Chinese Ambassador, Against the Tide Club members stood on the street with a banner saying: “June 4, 1989. The Tiananmen Square Massacre. We remember. ”

“We did not enter the area of the event, we did not block the passage”, says Mateusz from the Against the Tide Warsaw Club.

“Transparent began to arouse interest and positive reactions of passers-by. People started taking pictures of us. At this point, a group of Chinese people took out their Chinese and Polish flags, and began to block us out. In that case, we moved with the banner a few meters away, behind the Ambassador’s car. The Chinese with flags followed us and blocked out the banner again. At this point, the elegantly dressed Chinese woman began to talk to us in Polish, tell us to go away and not interrupt their party. When she heard that we were not entering the area of their event and that we were not disturbing its course and we were standing on a Polish street, she got nervous and she returned to the other Chinese people with flags and even pushed them on us (which can be seen in the film). She told them to follow us like a shadow and block out the banner”, said an eyewitness to the events.

Despite the fact that Poles were standing on the street, the Chinese attacked them: “At one point we were at the opposite side of the street, quite far from the Chinese party, but the Chinese with communist red flags followed us. They became aggressive, provocatively banging the flags on the banner, on our hands and on the camera. It was especially one Chinese woman in dark glasses who complained about us recording, because nobody allowed us. One of the movies shows how at some point he hits the camera hard”.

“They feel in Poland like in China. They think they have the right to ban filming to the Polish media! #Chinazi”, editor Hanna Shen, Against the Tide TV correspondent in Taiwan, commented on the scandalous situation in Warsaw.

However, Polish citizen journalists were not intimidated, they exercised their rights and peacefully picketed on Krakowskie Przedmieście. However, the Chinese, whose country is known for corruption, did not give up: “There was also an attempt to bribe us, one Chinese in a leather jacket showed a bundle of hundred-zloty bills and invited us to the cafe to “get along”. We also recorded it in the film”, says the coordinator of Against the Tide Warsaw club. Poles were not bribed and stood undeterred with a banner on the street.

Despite the physical attack of the Chinese on Poles, no police appeared at the scene. Poles did not experience any help from officers.

However, ordinary people responded positively to the Against the Tide’s banner: “People’s reactions, both Poles and foreigners’, were very positive. They were surprised by the way the Chinese acted, that they veiled our banner so intensely and did not allow us to stand still. Nobody may have stood up for us, but we saw that they supported us. A lot of people took pictures, showed friendly gestures, expressed positive attitude towards us”.

The Chinese event calls into question the anti-communist approach of the Law and Justice government. The celebrations are part of the campaign to promote communist China in Poland. No wonder, since President Andrzej Duda himself raised the rank of strategic partnership with China (concluded by President Bronisław Komorowski) to a comprehensive strategic partnership.

It is worth mentioning that at the same time on Piłsudski Square, near the place where commemorations of the communist China were celebrated, an event “Spark of Remembrance” dedicated to Poles murdered by Soviet communists in the Katyn forests in 1940 took place.

That is, there is no place for Soviet communism in Poland, but there is indeed enough room for the Chinese communism.
